channel.title: Hard drive (bad)luck
channel.description:
You guys may remember about 2 weeks ago when one of the hard drives went bad and was replaced with a new one, well, guess what? That new hard drive just went bad this morning. So we will again have a few moments of downtime while it is replaced. But with the RAID we shouldn't lose anything and should be back up in the time it takes to physically replace the drive and turn the machine back on.
Guess we will see how this all turns out shortly.

item.title: Hard drive (bad)luck
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:385555”]theyre talking shit, “8% of drives fail” makes no sense - 100% of drives fail

the usual statistic is mean time between failure[/quote]
I doubt it. It’s not like they have anything to gain or lose by making a blanket statement like that, and they probably have all the experience they need to make such remarks.

The MTBF for hard disks is, allegedly, 50000 hours iirc. What people overlook is the fact that if something is cheap for them, then production was cheap for the company – Seagate certainly isn’t taking a loss on their Barracuda range of hard disks.

So flagship drives of the companies, probably fine.
Drives bought on the cheap though? Do yourself a favour and spend a little more in my opinion.

item.title: Hard drive (bad)luck
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

No because the reason it didn’t work before was due to physical bad sectors on the disk (being read from). I don’t think hardware RAID would have made a difference.

Also, I don’t think hardware RAID would send me a nice email alerting me when things went south, would it? I did quite a bit of research before going to RAID, and the consensus everywhere is that software RAID is a much better alternative to the ‘fake raid’ that comes on nearly all motherboards. Though it may not be as good as a true, dedicated hardware RAID solution.

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

3 total, which over 2 years is starting to be ridiculous, but 1 failing after 2 weeks is complete madness!

Anyway, swap went great, downtime was what? Less than 10 minutes? And the new hard drive is back up and syncing as we speak:

[code]# cat /proc/mdstat
Personalities : [linear] [multipath] [raid0] [raid1] [raid6] [raid5] [raid4] [raid10]
md3 : active raid1 sdb4[2] sda4[1]
478471808 blocks [2/1] [_U]
[==>…] recovery = 13.5% (64610048/478471808) finish=433.8min speed=15896K/sec

md2 : active raid1 sdb2[1] sda2[0]
9767424 blocks [2/2] [UU]

md1 : active raid1 sdb1[1] sda1[0]
144448 blocks [2/2] [UU]

unused devices:
[/code]
This is how RAID is supposed to work!
